#Text=John Jones ( martyr )
#Text=John Jones OFM ( d. 12 July 1598 ) , also known as John Buckley , John Griffith , Godfrey Maurice , or Griffith Jones was a Franciscan friar , Roman Catholic priest , and martyr .
#Text=He was born at Clynnog Fawr , Caernarfonshire ( Gwynedd ) , Wales , and was executed 12 July 1598 at Southwark , England .
#Text=He is one of the Forty Martyrs of England and Wales .
#Text=Life
#Text=John Jones was born at Clynnog Fawr , Caernarfonshire ( Gwynedd ) , Wales .
#Text=He came from a recusant Welsh family , who had remained faithful Roman Catholics throughout the Protestant Reformation .
#Text=He was ordained a diocesan priest and was imprisoned in the Marshalsea under the name Robert Buckley from 1582 to about 1585 for administering the sacraments .
#Text=By summer 1586 he was out on bond , but in 1587 confined at Wisbech Castle . [ 1 ]
#Text=He left England , either escaped or exiled , in 1590 and at the age of sixty joined the Conventual Franciscans at Pontoise .
#Text=Afterwards he went to Rome , where he lived among the Observant Friars of the Ara Coeli .
#Text=After a time he was sent back by his superiors to the English mission ; and before leaving Rome he had an audience of Pope Clement VIII who embraced him and gave him his blessing . [ 2 ]
#Text=Jones reached London about the end of 1592 , and stayed temporarily at the house which Father John Gerard , S.J. , had provided for missionary priests , which house was managed by Anne Line .
#Text=Jones ministered to Catholics in the English countryside until his arrest in 1596 . [ 3 ]
#Text=In 1596 the ' priest catcher ' Richard Topcliffe was informed by a spy that Father Jones had visited two Catholics and had said Mass in their home .
#Text=It was later shown that the two Catholics were actually in prison when the alleged offense took place .
#Text=Regardless , Jones was arrested , severely tortured and scourged .

#Text=Topcliffe then took Jones to his house where he was further tortured , " To him ( Topcliffe ) was granted the privilege , unique in the laws of England , or , perhaps , of any country , of maintaining a private rack in his own home for the more convenient examination of prisoners . " [ 4 ]
#Text=Following his torture , Jones was imprisoned for nearly two years .
#Text=During this time Jones helped sustain John Rigby in his faith , who later also became one of the Forty Martyrs of England and Wales .

#Text=On 3 July 1598 Father Jones was tried on the charge of " going over the seas in the first year of Her majesty 's reign ( 1558 ) and there being made a priest by the authority from Rome and then returning to England contrary to statute " .
#Text=He was convicted of high treason and sentenced to be hanged , drawn and quartered .
#Text=A not entirely unsympathetic account of the executions of John Bodey and John Slade in 1583 was written by someone with the initials " R.B. " .

#Text=Historian John Hungerford Pollen S.J. suggests that it was written by a Catholic and further suggests that " R. B " could be Robert Barnes , who was convicted and hung fifteen years later for harboring John Jones . [ 5 ]
#Text=Also arrested for allegedly sheltering priests was Mrs. Jane Wiseman , who had two sons who were Jesuits .
#Text=Like Margaret Clitherow , Wiseman refused to enter a plea and was therefore condemned to the peine forte et dure , although she was eventually pardoned . [ 1 ] [ 6 ]
#Text=Execution
#Text=As by this time the people had grown tired of these butcheries , the execution was arranged for an early hour in the morning .

#Text=The place was St. Thomas 's Watering , a small bridge over the Neckinger crossing the Old Kent Road , at the site of the junction of the old Roman road to London with the main line of Watling Street .
#Text=This marked the boundary of the City of London 's authority ; it was also a place of gibbets .
#Text=The execution was delayed by about an hour because the hangman forgot to bring a rope .
#Text=Jones used the time to preach to the people and answer their questions . [ 7 ]
#Text=When the time came to draw away the cart , the hangman whipped the horses ; but they were held back by three or four fellows till Jones had finished what he was saying . [ 1 ]
#Text=John Jones ' dismembered remains were fixed atop poles on roads leading to Newington and Lambeth ( now represented by Tabard Street and Lambeth Road respectively ) .
#Text=His remains were later reputedly removed by at least two Catholic Englishmen , one of whom suffered a long imprisonment for this offense .
#Text=One of the relics eventually reached Pontoise , where Jones had taken his religious vows .
#Text=Veneration
#Text=John Jones was named Venerable by Pope Leo XIII and beatified in 1929 by Pope Pius XI with a feast day of 12 July .
#Text=He was canonized on 25 October 1970 by Pope Paul VI as one of the Forty Martyrs of England and Wales , who are commemorated on that date .
